headline: Trump said he took a cognitive test because he didn't 'like being called stupid'
author: Hannah Getahun
sentences: He continued, referencing an apparent conversation with Republican Rep. Ronny Jackson: "Is there a test or something I can take to prove to these radical left maniacs that are much smarter than them?"
Jackson, who represents Texas' 13th congressional district and served as White House physician under Trump and Former President Barack Obama, administered the test and said that Trump got 100% on it.
Jackson, along with other Republicans, called on President Joe Biden in an open letter to take the same test, saying that he was not "not physically or cognitively fit" to lead the county.

Trump said Thursday during a press conference in Florida that he would rather be called a dictator than a dumb person after boasting about the same test results.
Former U.S. President Donald Trump speaks during a rally hosted by the former president at the Delaware County Fairgrounds on April 23, 2022 in Delaware, Ohio.
Trump retorted by saying he "bet" that Wallace couldn't answer the last five questions and that "Joe Biden could not answer those questions."
Chris Wallace, who interviewed Trump in 2020, told the former president that he had also taken the exam, and it was "not the hardest test."

Drew Angerer/Getty Images
Former President Donald Trump said that he "didn't like being called stupid" during a rally in Ohio.

The test Trump referenced is called the Montreal Cognitive Assessment.
Trump asked Rep. Ronny Jackson if he could take a cognitive test, which Jackson later said he aced.
Representatives for Trump and Jackson did not immediately respond to Insider's request for comment.
During Saturday's rally in Ohio, Trump detailed once again that he aced a cognitive test in 2018.
It is not an IQ test but rather a tool to spot early signs of dementia and other memory issues.
Former President Trump apparently doesn't like his intelligence being called into question.

The exam is not an IQ test, but rather an indicator of memory loss.
Trump referenced the dictator comment during Saturday's rally.
"They say he's a dictator, he wants to take over the world."
"And you know, now, they don't call me stupid," Trump said.
